issue.title: Report debug messages during glob expansion
issue.body:
coala appears to hang whenever a glob takes a long time to expand.
This happens very frequently when it descends into node_modules/ .  There are other bugs about coala behaving better when descending a node_modules/, but typically nobody wants it to descend node_modules/, so this should be an error.
There should be regular debug messages during a glob expansion, including when they appear in files = .. and ignore = ...

issue.title: Maximum time to expand globs
issue.body:
There should be a setting for max time to expand globs, and an error if glob expansion takes longer than the setting.
Default should be one minute.
See #5966 for background about why.
Low difficulty for only emitting an error if the max was exceeded.
Medium difficulty to also stop expanding the glob when the max is exceeded, i.e. for it to be a timeout.
As a follow up issue, to be created after this is completed, coala should stop processing only effected sections, and continue processing unaffected sections.  Thus is needs to determine which sections would be effected by the glob.

issue.title: Adding_CI.rst: Section on Circle CI
issue.body:
In Adding_CI.rst, we have a section on Circle CI.
It appears to me that we are no longer using Circle CI (the last build for coala/coala was 2 months ago and for coala/coala-bears was 6 months ago (which is still running on the unsupported CircleCI 1.0). Also the link to coala's circle.yml is broken.
There are two solutions to this:

If we are no longer using Circle CI (which appears to be the case) then the section or at least the link needs to be removed.
If we are using it, we still need to remove/update the link and also upgrade to Circle CI 2.0 for coala-bears (which should be done via a separate issue).

This issue requires some advice and input from the maintainers but regardless of that, this would be an issue that is suitable for newcomers.

issue.body:
Travis build for coala/coala-bears/#2836 is failing with the following error:
# golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter
../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter/bexport.go:212: obj.IsAlias undefined (type *types.TypeName has no field or method IsAlias)

../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/packagesdriver/sizes.go:94: undefined: types.SizesFor
The command ".ci/deps.go.sh" failed and exited with 2 during .

This problem persists if an old verion of Go language is used according to this issue which states that Go <= 1.8 is no longer supported.
Currently Travis CI testing is done on trusty, so either the latest version of golang needs to be manually installed in trusty images or an updated version of ubuntu needs to be used for testing.
Further input from maintainers is required to come at a conclusion.
EDIT: CI related issue area/ci

issue.title: Create a line length test helper
issue.body:
A line length test helper will take a chunk of source , and a regex, and verify the bear accepts source under the line length and rejects lines over the line length.
The max_line_length setting can be automatically determined by the lines in the source provided by the caller.  The bear should pass this test.
The regex is then used to increase the size of the source line lengths by 1 character, in accordance with the source language rules.
The helper confirms that the source was increased by 1 character only, and re-runs the bear, and expects it to fail.

issue.title: Support Python 3.4.x
issue.body:
Python 3.4.0-3 were dropped because of 8a08cd2, due to Python <3.4.4 not having asyncio.run_coroutine_threadsafe.  This has only happened in the current dev release.
However package trollius provides that on Python 2.7+
Python 3.4.3 is used as the Trusty default, so supporting it has benefit to users and especially to CI which uses that by default for all non-Python languages.
It also means the platform requirements of 0.11 will continue to be supported by the next release.

issue.title: Nextgen-Core: Raise exception in core.run() when bear or result-callback raised an exception
issue.body:
Currently the core properly cleans up the failing bear and discards all dependent tasks and bears, and then swallows the exception.
However, coala (and other users) needs to know that something didn't work perfectly, for example returning an error code that some analysis was run, but couldn't complete due to errors.
I propose to write a custom exception that aggregates all those swallowed exceptions and is then raised in core.run().
class Exceptions(Exception):
    def __init__(self, exceptions):
        super().__init__('Multiple exceptions happened:\n' + '\n\n'.join(str(ex) for ex in exceptions)
        self.exceptions = exceptions
To make use of it, the core Session has another field, e.g. self.silent_errors or self.recovered_errors (or similar), where all components can put in their errors if they can recover from them. When exiting the run, the Session checks if exceptions were placed into self.silent_errors/self.recovered_errors, constructs an Exceptions instance with all of those errors and raises it in the main thread.
Acceptance criteria:

An exception is implemented that is capable of storing multiple exceptions and emitting an appropriate error message
core.run() raises this exception if at least one bear or result-callback failed. The raised exception provides information on all exceptions occurred and swallowed inside core.run().

issue.title: Add output mode to emit a unified diff
issue.body:
It can be useful to use coala to obtain a patch file of fixes that have been found by the bears.
For simplicity, unified diff output format should be the only format initially.
--json will be a bit of a guide on how to do this.
One way to solve this is to write a converter of the JSON output to a unified diff format, discarding all the non-fix results.

issue.title: The glob `*` does not match all bears
issue.body:
Many bears' result.origin is not just the name of the bear. For e.g.. ESLintBear has result.origin "ESLintBear (prettier/prettier)" and the glob * doesn't match anything with file seperators in it i.e. / or \, we have to use glob **. The PR #5017 fixes the issue with --apply-patches command line argument but if the .coafile has something like this
default_actions = *: ApplyPatchAction

This may not match all bears. This needs to be solved. Many things can be done to solve this eg:


The result.origin of those bears can be changed


I don't think that any user will think this through and use glob * specifically to ignore such bears so we can internally change all the glob * to **


We can prompt the user that some bears won't if they ever use the glob *


status/needs discussion on what is the best solution

issue.title: .coafile not showing the correct error
issue.body:
An earlier typo in .coafile which is being fixed by #5043 doesn't show the correct error message. Instead it shows an error based on the previous line
eg. if your .coafile has this
use_spaces = true
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
 Unable to convert parameter 'use_spaces' into type <class 'bool'>.

if your .coafile is
files = *.txt
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

It will show Unable to find that file/ No matching file
or if your .coafile is
bears = SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction

it will show
No bears matching 'SpaceConsistencyBear
default_action: **: ApplyPatchAction' were found. Make sure you have coala-bears installed or you have typed the name correctly.

Instead it should point out the error in the statement itself

issue.title: Bear Results not displayed in correct order
In `ask_for_action_and_apply()`, if `apply_single` is non-False, function should return when match is found
issue.body:
In the function ask_for_action_and_apply() in ConsoleInteraction.py, if the apply_single parameter is non-False, then the for loop inside it iterates through the entire metadata_list before returning False.
IMHO we should include a break statement inside the if block (which is in the for loop) such that the function may return after a match is found because there is no need to go through the remaining actions in metadata_list.

|    | *0: Do nothing
|    |  1: Open file(s)

issue.title: nltk~=3.2 is not sufficient
issue.body: A recent change to the VCS bears used a feature of nltk not found in v3.2 ; correct minimum version needed.

issue.title: RELEASE_NOTES.rst: Expired Link
issue.body:
In the file, RELEASE_NOTES.rst , the link to the list of Major API changes, in the line 391, has expired and the list is not found.
The link needs to be updated.

issue.title: Travis build failing due to old version of golang
issue.body:
Travis build for coala/coala-bears/#2836 is failing with the following error:
# golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter
../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/gcimporter/bexport.go:212: obj.IsAlias undefined (type *types.TypeName has no field or method IsAlias)
# golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/packagesdriver
../../../gopath/src/golang.org/x/tools/go/internal/packagesdriver/sizes.go:94: undefined: types.SizesFor
The command ".ci/deps.go.sh" failed and exited with 2 during .

This problem persists if an old verion of Go language is used according to this issue which states that Go <= 1.8 is no longer supported.
Currently Travis CI testing is done on trusty, so either the latest version of golang needs to be manually installed in trusty images or an updated version of ubuntu needs to be used for testing.
Further input from maintainers is required to come at a conclusion.
area/ci
type/bug

The link for the coala-bears usage further navigates to this which has no information about how to use coala. One can do either of the following:


Update the link so that it navigates to the coala documentation.


Add usage information in the README.rst file located here.


Maintainers can suggest the correct way.

issue.title: LineContinuationBear: Ignore backslashes in triple-quoted strings automatically
issue.body:
The line continuation bear should ignore line endings with backslash(es) in strings automatically.
For example, these lines should be ignored:
"""
    OrderedDict([(<Version('2.7')>, ('#',)), (<Version('3.3')>, ('#',)), \
(<Version('3.4')>, ('#',)), (<Version('3.5')>, ('#',)), \
(<Version('3.6')>, ('#',))])
"""

issue.title: LineContinuationBear: Ignore backslashes in `from` imports inside doctest
issue.body:
The bear should ignore the backslashes in from imports.
Here's an example:
"""
        >>> from coalib.bearlib.languages.documentation.DocumentationComment \
        ...     import DocumentationComment
"""

issue.title: LineContinuationBear: Ignore backslashes in `with`
issue.body:
There should be a feature in the line continuation bear to ignore backslashes used in with statements.

coala wouldn't use that feature, but I suspect many people would like to keep the backslashes when used in a with statement. - jayvdb

issue.title: Disable InferBear
issue.body: Due to #2664 completely failing now, a quick workaround is to disable the opam & infer, so that travis CI doesnt try to set up the pre-reqs, and so that the coverage is still 100%

issue.title: README.rst: Update the FAQ Link
issue.body:
The link in the Installation section of the file README.rst can be updated to the latest link:
http://docs.coala.io/en/latest/Help/FAQ.html
This can be a suitable issue for newcomers.

issue.title: Bear Proposal: whale-linter dockerfile linter
issue.body: https://github.com/jeromepin/whale-linter

issue.title: Broken URL in URLHeadBear.py
issue.body:
The default URL currently being used to check for internet connectivity, http://216.58.218.174 appears to be broken.
The HEAD request to this URL fails and hence the InvalidLinkBear, throwing an error [ERROR][14:16:23] The bear InvalidLinkBear does not fulfill all requirements. You are not connected to the internet.
URL can be changed to 1.1.1.1 DNS IP by Cloudfare.

issue.title: README.rst: Typo in the words `newcomers' guide`
issue.body:
There is a link to newcomers' guide in README.rst, but it has been spelled as newcomer guide. To make it grammatically correct and to remain consistent with the rest of the docs and the website, it should be corrected.
This could be a suitable issue for newcomers.

issue.title: pycodestyle silently discarding warnings
issue.body:
Whilst working on coverage issues, I found that if I require all pycodestyle lines match the regex, the following occurs.
[ERROR][03:47:24] Bear PycodestyleBear failed to run on file /home/travis/build/coala/coala-bears/bears/vcs/git/GitCommitBear.py. Take a look at debug messages (`-V`) for further information.
[DEBUG][03:47:24] The bear PycodestyleBear raised an exception. If you are the author of this bear, please make sure to catch all exceptions. If not and this error annoys you, you might want to get in contact with the author of this bear.
Traceback information is provided below:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6.3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/coalib/bears/Bear.py", line 454, in execute
    return [] if result is None else list(result)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6.3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/bears/python/PycodestyleBear.py", line 78, in process_output
    line, column, message, rule = result.groups()
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'groups'
https://travis-ci.org/coala/coala-bears/jobs/452210806
When spitting out the lines causing this, I find
[WARNING][04:04:11] Unexpected output 45 -303 W605 invalid escape sequence '\d'
[WARNING][04:04:31] Unexpected output 250 -55 W605 invalid escape sequence '\*'
259 -52 W605 invalid escape sequence '\|'
..

https://travis-ci.org/coala/coala-bears/jobs/452214629
All are in docstrings.  The first is in bears/vcs/git/GitCommitBear.py for the \d

by GitHub in a refs/pull/(\d+)/merge git remote reference.

The second and third are bears/c_languages/codeclone_detection/ClangCountingConditions.py

statement, i.e. within the operators *, /, % and their associated compound


operation, i.e. within the operators |, & and their associated compound

There are two problems here, and they need to be fixed at the same time to avoid breaking the build.


pycodestyle isnt capturing all warnings, and was silently discarding them.


those errors are roughly correct and need to be fixed.


The \d is easy fixed.
The other two are much more problematic, as removing the \ causes sphinx-build to then emit a warning:
Warning, treated as error:
/home/travis/build/coala/coala-bears/bears/c_languages/codeclone_detection/ClangCountingConditions.py:docstring of bears.c_languages.codeclone_detection.ClangCountingConditions.in_binary_operation:1:Inline substitution_reference start-string without end-string.

Currently, all the coala CLI interactions occur through numeric inputs which is very slow and cumbersome in most cases. This can be improved greatly by building more interactive CLIs using tools like PyInquirer. We have a lot of areas where the CLI can be improved.
For example we can use:

the checkbox question type for coala-quickstart.
the checkbox question type again when we run coala.

Apart from replacing number based inputs, we can:

add auto-complete in prompting for bears in both coala and coala-quickstart.
add a fuzzy finder like in git when we enter an invalid option to the CLI.

This could be a GSoC size project once all the potential areas of implementation are identified.
Note: If you're not familiar with using such CLIs, checkout:

npm/yarn
eslint CLI - eslint --init

issue.title: coala - A Smartphone Application
issue.body:
Project Proposal Idea
In today's digital world, every individual or a contributor uses a smartphone. And, it becomes difficult to carry laptops everywhere or using a website to browse through issues or commenting on a PR via mobile. For not to happen this, we can create a one-stop application for developers or contributors that can help them to know about our org and provide some features/functionalities to them so that they can contribute to our org, from anywhere at anytime.
Sometimes, a contributors gets into a situation where they think that "I can do much better things then what I am currently doing" or "I can utilize this free time what I have got", this way if they were contributing to our org or want to so some contribution, then that contributor can use this app to know about the org and can do much more things that I will be explaining further what all can a contributor do with this app.
We can provide following features/functionalities to contributors:


Newcomer's Section

Netlify-form link (existing issue in community repository ) or we can create a form layout in mobile-app that can somehow send an API request to netlify-form (if possible), the form will be used to join coala org asking about user details and taking input of an issue reference on which the user want to work (optional)
List out all newcomer issues
display the joining's of new contributors in past month and past year, to motivate the new joining user



Integrate-coala

Will work online as well as offline
OFFLINE: Any project in mobile storage will not require internet to run coala on it.
ONLINE: Any project uploaded on GitHub or on any other service, requires internet to fetch files.



About and Settings section


Feedback form


PR pending for review

Either redirect user to web-page on choosing a PR or display all comments under a PR on the app itself
User/Contributor can also comment on a PR



User profile

Created Issues/PR
rest all the mandatory sections that are always present in a profile section



Create an Issue form


For now, this is all what I have in mind. I was too thinking about applying Machine Learning somehow but that's just a thought. Will think on it definitely on how can we achieve this.
Your thoughts are valuable to me, please add a comment if you want to add some new ideas to this project proposal.

issue.title: Support TOML as another settings file format
issue.body:
According to https://github.com/toml-lang/toml
TOML aims to be a minimal configuration file format that's easy to read due to obvious semantics. TOML is designed to map unambiguously to a hash table. TOML should be easy to parse into data structures in a wide variety of languages.
TOML has widespread acceptance, documentation and robust parsers.
Also according to https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0518/, TOML is

Human-usable (unlike JSON ),
Flexible (unlike configparser),
Stems from a standard (unlike configparser)
Not overly complex (unlike YAML).

Also TOML has been recommended as the configuration file for software packages to specify their build dependencies.
 pyproject.toml is being used for this purpose. https://github.com/pypa/pip/blob/master/pyproject.toml
coala could provide TOML as a additional setting format.

By following a well known standard like TOML, we would reduce the learning curve involved.
When the current system gets complex, TOML will be a better choice than a custom INI.
It provides flexibility, consistency, backwards compatibility and stems from a standard all of which are drawbacks of configparser.

This proposal issue is about supporting a new config file like coafile.toml along with .coafile.
coala/coala#4609

issue.title: Result reporter tool
issue.body:
The coala json format provides a stable output.
There are other formats which are useful for reporting tests and failures.
Most commonly used is JUnit format. (which isnt really a specified format; see https://blog.ilias.xyz/unit-test-output-formats-a-state-of-affairs-5734b4c8e577)
Converting the static analysis results into a test results format has been done a few times, such as early PEP8 plugins to Jenkins.  The mapping isnt exact, but the benefits of using the test result format is tight integration with various system.
CircleCI can accept this format: https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/collect-test-data/
AppVeyor can receive a test results XML format, in the format output by xunit, presumably the same as JUnit.
https://www.appveyor.com/docs/running-tests/#uploading-xml-test-results
The first project phase could involve converting the JSON to JUnit format and uploading into Circle CI and Appveyor.
The JUnit format should also be tested with a Jenkins install, to ensure it is uploading correctly there.  This would mean our Jenkins project is much less important.
Another common format is TAP.
And there is Clover XML format.
Then there are some system, such as Phabricator, which have a custom format they expect.
c.f. facebook/infer#673
The above probably doesnt fill 3 months.
Pulling the coala results from CI using this format could be a way to inform newbies of the style problems with their PRs.
Another way to expand this project is to also push the unit test results as XML to the CI (using combination XML files if necessary)

issue.body:
In python 3.6, Unknown escapes consisting of \ and an ASCII letter in regular expressions will

Owing to it pycodestyle have added this check for future Python versions.

**** PycodestyleBear (W605) [Section: all.autopep8 | Severity: NORMAL] **** !    ! W605 invalid escape sequence '\(' labhub_test.py
**** PycodestyleBear (W605) [Section: all.autopep8 | Severity: NORMAL] **** !    ! W605 invalid escape sequence '\(' ban_test.py

File "/home/kvgarg/GSOC/Coala Open Source/community/community/urls.py", line 12, in <module>

issue.body: It would be good to design the contributors page http://coala-community.netlify.com/contributors/ with bootstrap cards https://www.w3schools.com/bootstrap4/bootstrap_cards.asp

issue.title: Remove use of IGitt's write_repositories
issue.body:
Using IGitt's write_repositories allows easy access to the repositories, but it is not necessary.
This may need upstream enhancements.

issue.title: Add pages showing the org teams
issue.body:
I think want at least the coala maintainers, coala developers and coala newcomer teams to have a page, with a list of team members similar to https://coala.io/#/getinvolved .
I think it is OK to have a page about all teams in https://github.com/orgs/coala/teams .
However we also need a way to name our temporary teams so that they do not appear on the website.
e.g. @adtac created a team to help him manage inactive newcomers at coala/meta#74 , so they could be removed.  Maybe we dont want a team like that appearing on the website ;-)

issue.title: Add status to issues tasks in tasks.yaml
issue.body:
When a task has max_instances: 1 and an issues URL , it can be annotated with an extra attribute to indicate the task status: available, claimed or completed.
Instance are exported as instances.yaml , and indicate whether the task is in progress or completed.
Completed issues are the easiest to work with.
In progress tasks are slightly more complicated because the publish instances are filtered to remove tasks still in early phases of the task lifecycle.  See https://github.com/coala/community/blob/master/gci/students.py#L84

issue.title: Create a Netlify form for joining the community
issue.body:
Netlify forms can be used to let people 'become a developer' from their web browser.  It allows signing using GitHub, for authenticated collection of their username to be added to the org.  We could also add a field for the issue they want to be assigned to.
It is then easy for maintainers to invite them to the org after some rudimentary checks, or add a http://webtask.io which automatically invites them if they pass some basic automated checks to prevent abuse.
Probably a good app name is '/join'

issue.title: README.rst: Add setup instructions to README.md
issue.body:
Currently, in README.md there is no information provided on how to run coala-html on a project which makes difficult for a new contributor on how to and what commands should be used to run coala-html.
So, need command instruction's with a small description what each command does to the README.md.
IMO we should add instructions from installing nodejs till the executing instruction of coala-html.
Make sure to use keyword sudo where needed in terminal commands.
This could be a suitable issue for newcomers.

issue.title: Group results based on the file they belong to
issue.body:
Currently, irrespective of a file the results belong, they're being shown all at once. It'd look like mess when we have results for say 20 different files or even more and each file having 10 source ranges. Imagine, user will have to scroll all the way down to go through all the files' results.
Now we can do two things to avoid this:

Display only file names in result tab. Clicking on the file names would display all the results for corresponding file. Clicking on another file would close the results for previous one and open for the current file. Can be done with simple toggle.
Use pagination in case when number of files are large.

IMO 2nd option seems sustainable
cc @AbdealiJK @sils1297

issue.title: Add warning signs for directories that contains files where results were produced
issue.body: At present, only files are being shown with warning icons. It'd be nice to show warning icon to the parent directories of the affected files too.

This could be a suitable issue for newcomers.

issue.title: docs.coala.io: Header's aspect ratio not consistent (in mobile browsers)
issue.body:
Overview Description
The coala header in https://docs.coala.io/en/latest/ gets scaled only horizontally when viewed using mobile browsers leading to a distortion of the logo. It would be better if the consistency of the logo is maintained, else the koala bear starts looking like a starved chipmunk 
Steps to Reproduce

Open https://docs.coala.io/en/latest/ in any mobile web browser (portrait mode)

Actual Results

Expected Results
If the image scales while preserving aspect ratio and is aligned to the center or to the left, the logo would remain round.

issue.body:
This issue is very similar to #299. Everything there holds true for this one, just that this one is for api.coala.io instead of docs.coala.io.
This would make a nice newcomer issue. Once one of them is solved, the person can follow the same process to solve the other one.

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,85 @@
+Testing coala change on coala-bears
+===================================
+
+When large changes are made to the coala core, they should be tested
+on the coala-bears to confirm that they work as expected and don't
+break anything on the bears' side.
+
+There was an attempt to automate this through
+https://github.com/coala/coala/pull/4424 which used to depend upon docker
+image, but unfortunately the image breaks stuff for now.
+
+But we can still do it manually, by changing the coala dependency for the
+bears to be the one consisting of the changes made For which we need to create
+a new branch on coala-bears, edit the requirements and run it on CI.
+
+Set-up a new testing branch
+---------------------------
+
+Assuming we have already made changes to coala through a new branch, we can
+use the branch to install coala instead of master by editing requirements.txt
+file in coala-bears. So, lets set-up a new branch on coala-bears for these
+changes.
+
+If you have not already, clone your fork by running:
+
+::
+
+    $ git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/coala-bears
+
+Make sure that you replace <your-username> with your corresponding github
+username.
+
+Now, navigate to the directory where coala-bears is located.
+
+::
+
+    $ cd coala-bears
+
+Before making any change, switch to a new branch (other than master).
+
+::
+
+    $ git checkout -b new_test_branch
+
+.. note::
+    Never make any changes on your master branch.
+    See `Git Tutorial <https://coala.io/gitbasics>`_ for more info.
+
+Now you've done that, you are free to make changes.
+
+Change coala dependency in requirements.txt
+-------------------------------------------
+
+First thing we need is to change the coala dependency.
+
+Now assuming you have made changes to coala fork on branch <branch-name>, you
+can edit the coala dependency by changing the corresponding line to:
+
+::
+
+    git+https://github.com/<your-username>/coala@<branch-name>#egg=coala
+
+Set-up CI to run on your branch
+-------------------------------
+
+Since you need the tests to be ran on CI, set it up by modifying respective
+configuration files. You can have a look at our
+`CI Tutorial <https://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Adding_CI.html>`_.
+for more info.
+
+For example, to run `travis-ci <https://travis-ci.org/>`_ on your
+branch you could modify .travis.yml file. At the end of the file, you'll find
+branch specification where you could white-list your branch name. So you should
+have the change as following:
+
+::
+
+    branches:
+      only:
+        - new_test_branch
+
+Simillarly, you can make changes to appveyor.yml file to run tests on AppveyorCI

issue.title: coala_main.py: Changes Ctrl-Z to Ctrl-Z-Enter
issue.body:
Fixes #5254

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: Ctrl-Z-Enter would look like we need to press all the 3 keys simultaneously. But iirc, The proper way to send an EOF signal in Windows is to press Ctrl-Z followed by Enter. So something like, Ctrl-Z followed by Enter would seem more appropriate.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ def do_nothing(*args):
 
 
 STR_ENTER_LETTER = 'Enter letter (Ctrl-{} to exit): '.format(
-    'Z' if platform.system() == 'Windows' else 'D')
+    'Z-Enter' if platform.system() == 'Windows' else 'D')

issue.title: OpenEditorAction.py: Add Brackets in known editors
issue.body:
This adds Brackets to the list of editors known to coala.
Closes #5829
It was mentioned in the documentation that "Brackets can be launched from the command line, but it does not accept arguments."
Reference : https://github.com/adobe/brackets/wiki/Command-Line-Arguments

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText: Can you please explain you reason for this change. Why is it only {filename}? And doesn't it take any args? Is there a reason you missed it?
Never mind. Found my answers at https://github.com/adobe/brackets/wiki/Command-Line-Arguments#linux. Thanks for the reference. This PR looks good to me now :)
This is good enough. Even passing the filename wouldn't load the file, it would simply just open the editor.
add trailing comma

issue.title: coala_modes.py: Add a new mode to emit diff
issue.body:
This commit adds a new mode to coala. This mode will emit the patches obtained by the bears in unified diff format. To use this mode command is coala --diff. If the user wants to specify output file, --output can be used.
Closes #5379

ok thanks

@akshatkarani if i delete this 8515861 commit. Would my PR gets deleted ?

It won't delete the PR, if you delete that commit.
You can delete that commit easily by using git interactive mode in terminal.
But, you need to squash your commits to one commit. Refer squashing section to know how to get into the interactive mode. Also, while you get into interactive mode, github provides some additional information on the terminal screen, please read those information carefully, as it will help you.
Also, use git commit --amend to add new local changes to your previous commit and then you can easily push this commit, without making an additional commits to the PR.

issue.title: Python 3.4.3 support
issue.body:
Closes #5891
Sits on top of #5893

comments.bodyText: Why is 3.4.3 not here?

it would slow down all builds, unnecessarily.
We could add it to master builds.
Or I think we can also only run jobs on the nightly cron, which would reduce delays if multiple PRs are getting merged.

What is the benefit of using moban to copy async.py from https://github.com/NAStools/homeassistant/blob/master/homeassistant/util/async.py? That project seems to be out of maintenance.
Drawbacks I can see:

licence is not stated in async.py, but in this file.
async.py needs to be excluded in .coafile.
async.py has other functions, e.g. fire_coroutine_threadsafe, which we don't use.
We cannot easily test it.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -65,3 +67,6 @@ targets:
   - netlify.toml: docs/netlify.toml
   - .misc/appveyor.yml: ci/appveyor.yml.jj2
   - .misc/run_with_env.cmd: run_with_env.cmd
+copy:
+  # homeassistant license MIT
+  - coalib/misc/Asyncio.py: async.py

comments.bodyText:
The reason to do it this way is so that external code is 'managed'.  We can improve the way it is managed by improving moban.
Your point '3' is the only significant problem, and that can be solved by moban having patch support, so we can exclude the other code e.g. moremoban/moban#75 . A header can also be added using a patch.
I am not worried about the licensing being missing from the file, as anyone modifying this file will likely be informed via code review, or will be reverted when someone looks at the moban job.  We should distribute the MIT license, and any other license of code we're including, but by no means is this "substantial portions" according to the MIT license so we're not breaking the license by not including it.  And by having a control file which mentions where code came from, and thus were the license text can be found, we're not hiding the fact the code is copied.
The fact it is unmaintained is a problem for the future, as PRs upstream will not get merged.  Again, a .patch could solve that, but i would expect that this type of code would be moved to a new coala-compat package, or something like that, or a sub-module of coala-utils.
Same with the .coafile problems.  A patch can fix it.
The drawbacks of not doing it:

another piece of copied code will fade into the coala codebase and its history effectively lost
coala doesnt have a process for allowing externally written code into the repo.
moban doesnt have a user (coala) pushing for it to handle more complicated scenarios than just 'copy'.
coala doesnt start the process of identifying and fixing any existing copied code.  This one is MIT, but we will likely find some which isnt so freely licensed.  e.g. we have CC-BY-SA-licensed 'code' in some repos, and a major issue over in coala-quickstart
etc.

Being in .moban.yaml is an annoyance.  That is intentional ;-)

issue.title: Do not error hard because a dependency of a bear has been updated
issue.body:
Currently, upon a simple load of bears, we implicitly check every single dependency to see if it's exactly as any given bear hard pins to antequated versions and fail hard if you are even slightly off. I don't see a reason this should be the case as this is Python; it's not coala's concern whether I've installed a later isort version than it expects, especially not at runtime.
This simple fix merely resolves each entrypoint instead, which is really what we're trying to do anyway.

comments.bodyText:
Hi, if you want to contribute to coala, the best way is to follow coala's contribution guide. http://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Newcomers_Guide.html That is, you'd better create an issue first, describe what improvement you want, get assigned and then work on it.
btw load() function doesn't have argument 'require'.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -452,7 +452,9 @@ def collect_registered_bears_dirs(entrypoint):
     for ep in pkg_resources.iter_entry_points(entrypoint):
         registered_package = None
         try:
-            registered_package = ep.load()
+            # backwards compat with old setuptools that do not provide Entrypoint.resolve
+            meth = getattr(ep, 'resolve', functools.partial(ep.load, require=False))

Nice solution, but the last line of the commit message needs to refer to an issue, not the same PR.
I suggest using "Related to #4085" or "Related to #3545" as the two closest open issues to the problem that you are solving.
Or you can create a new issue about it.
Then, the other problem with this lovely hack is we need to know what is the minimum version of setuptools/pkg_resources where this hack works.
What would be really nice (but not mandatory) is if this little hack was packaged up in a separate repo & pypi package with its own CI to ensure it keeps working with new releases of setuptools.

On the last line: Sure thing, I will update today. I was unsure on that.

As for the minimum version, it would work on at the very least but not
limited to the same versions as before, since it falls back took the
original behavior.

I do agree it would be nice to have automated detection of external API
usage breakage in some manner or another in some version of our future.

This gets rather messy to find the lowest version of setuptools, as pkg_resources uses vendored packaging for the code in question, and to make matters worse distros then do unvendoring, so there are a variety of packaging versions to consider for distro based installs, and a variety of setuptools versions to consider for pypi based installs.
I think we should create a separate issue about it, and work on it after this is merged.  We do know that this works, albeit we have no tests to confirm it.
https://pypi.org/project/entrypoints/ might be helpful.

issue.title: RELEASE_NOTES.rst: Fix broken bear API changes URL
issue.body:
The new URL points to a freshly compiled list of bear API changes in release 0.8.0.
Closes #2840

Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.

The compiled list of API changes can be found on this non-expiring paste and below.

Click to view changes list

coala release 0.8.0
https://github.com/coala
    
    Bear API Changes

    Settings unification - most bears have seen API changes. Settings' names are now consistent across
    bears. This supports backwards compatibility, however (but with a deprecation notice). 
    You can find the whole list here.
    
    Changes marked with (n) are negated booleans
    

ClangComplexityBear
    max_complexity -> cyclomatic_complexity
    
CoffeeLintBear
    tab_width                           -> indent_size                          
    no_decr_or_incrementation_operators -> allow_increment                      (n) 
    no_empty_parameter_list             -> allow_no_parameters                  (n) 
    no_empty_functions                  -> allow_empty_functions                (n) 
    no_this                             -> allow_this_statements                (n) 
    no_implicit_parentheses             -> allow_implicit_parentheses           (n) 
    no_interpolation_in_single_quotes   -> allow_interpolation_in_single_quotes (n) 
    no_stand_alone_at_sign              -> allow_stand_alone_at_sign            (n) 
    disable_throwing_strings            -> allow_throwing_strings               (n) 
    no_unnecessary_double_quotes        -> allow_unnecessary_double_quotes      (n) 
    use_english_operator                -> allow_bitwise_operators              (n) 
    no_implicit_braces                  -> force_braces                         

FormatRBear
    tab_width -> indent_size

GNUIndentBear
    tab_width -> indent_size
    
IndentationBear
    tab_width -> indent_size
    
JSHintBear
    maxcomplexity                    -> cyclomatic_complexity            
    prohibit_unused                  -> allow_unused_variables           (n)
    maxparams                        -> max_parameters                   
    allow_missing_semicol            -> allow_missing_semicolon          
    allow_this_stmt                  -> allow_this_statements            
    allow_with_stmt                  -> allow_with_statements            
    prohibit_bitwise                 -> allow_bitwise_operators          (n) 
    maxstatements                    -> max_statements                   
    maxdepth                         -> max_depth                        
    prohibit_comma                   -> allow_comma_operator             (n) 
    prohibit_non_breaking_whitespace -> allow_non_breaking_whitespace    (n) 
    prohibit_prototype_overwrite     -> allow_prototype_overwrite        (n) 
    prohibit_type_coercion           -> allow_type_coercion              (n) 
    future_hostile                   -> allow_future_identifiers         (n) 
    prohibit_typeof                  -> allow_typeof                     (n) 
    prohibit_variable_statements     -> allow_var_statement              (n) 
    prohibit_groups                  -> allow_grouping_operator          (n) 
    shadow                           -> allow_variable_shadowing             
    using_mozilla                    -> use_mozilla_extension            
    prohibit_new                     -> allow_constructor_functions      (n) 
    prohibit_arg                     -> allow_argument_caller_and_callee (n) 
    iterator                         -> allow_iterator_property          (n) 
    force_filter_forin               -> allow_filter_in_forin                
    
JSONFormatBear 
    tab_width    -> indent_size    
    keep_unicode -> escape_unicode (n)                

JavaPMDBear
    check_unnecessary -> allow_unnecessary_code (n)  
    check_unused      -> allow_unused_code      (n)  
                    
LanguageToolBear
    locale -> language
    
LineLengthBear
    tab_width -> indent_size

MatlabIndentationBear
    tab_width -> indent_size
    
PEP8Bear
    tab_width -> indent_size
    
PyImportSortBear
    tab_width -> indent_size
    
RuboCopBear
    tab_width             -> indent_size                  
    method_count_comments -> method_length_count_comments 

RubySmellBear
    duplicate_method_call -> allow_duplicate_method               (n) 
    data_clump            -> allow_data_clump                     (n) 
    control_parameter     -> allow_control_parameters             (n) 
    class_variable        -> allow_class_variables                (n) 
    boolean_parameter     -> allow_boolean_parameter_in_functions (n) 
    attribute             -> allow_setter_in_classes              (n) 
    unused_private_method -> allow_unused_private_methods         (n) 
    unused_params         -> allow_unused_variables               (n) 
        
SpaceConsistencyBear
    tab_width -> indent_size

WriteGoodLintBear
    check_passive_voice  -> allow_passive_voice   (n) 
    check_so_beginning   -> allow_so_beginning    (n) 
    check_adverbs        -> allow_adverbs         (n) 
    check_repeated_words -> allow_repeated_words  (n) 
    check_there_is       -> allow_there_is        (n) 
    check_ambiguos_words -> allow_ambiguous_words (n) 
    check_extra_words    -> allow_extra_words     (n) 
    check_cliche_exists  -> allow_cliche_phrases  (n) 

YapfBear
    tab_width -> indent_size

issue.title: PySafetyBear.py: Add proxy positional argument
issue.body:
The newer Safety package(v1.8.5) now adds the
functionality to support proxies which the Requests
package of Python uses.
The above functionality by Safety has been provided
by adding an extra positional argument called proxy
in the saftey.check() function. This caused the
TypeError in the previous version of Safety,due to
mismatch of number of positional argument
Closes #2857

issue.title: CI: Fix Pycodestyle warning W605
issue.body:
W605 is a warning for invalid escape sequences.
In python 3.6, Unknown escapes consisting of \ and an ASCII letter in regular expressions will
cause an warning.In the upcoming python versions this would be treated as an error.
Owing to it pycodestyle have added this check for future Python versions.
The alternative way to escape special characters now is to append a extra \ infront of the
sequences. Escape the characters by double backticks.
Fixes #2760

comments.bodyText:
commit message doesn't say why ignoring is appropriate solution

@jayvdb The reason I ignored the W605(Invalid escape sequence) was for a quick fix for travis CI. Which I realized was a wrong thing to do( Never silence an error to make your test pass :P)
I have been going through the past PR's from the pycodestyle repo and other repo's which were facing such issues. Looking at the history of out PR builds. Travis started to fail because of this error somewhere around December 2 -  2018(Everything before this Pr did not output the current error with Travis Sentinel, but after this PR sentinel started to have problems). Before that W605 existed but never poised the current problem. I am yet to understand what caused it.
Reading the comment here and the Issue, the better solution to the current failure of Travis would be to either escape the sequences such as '\d' by adding an extra \ or by r'\d'.
After trying out the above method on my fork, I realised that we have more than 4 files which needs to be fixed else the W605 warning will persist.
I would love to have your opinions on this.

The best option right now would be to wrap all the invalid escape sequences with r" ", in all the 4 files.
Moreover, why did PycodestyleBear start emitting W605 all of a sudden? I couldn't find any erroneous commit that could've resulted in this behavior. Did something change upstream?

Why hasnt this been updated??  At the very least your commit message is useless, and it is referencing an issue which was closed as a duplicate.  Stop looking for other people to guide you to the best solution, especially not from maintainers.  Find the best possible solution yourself, or listen to the best advice from other community members.

Why hasnt this been updated?? At the very least your commit message is useless, and it is referencing an issue which was closed as a duplicate. Stop looking for other people to guide you to the best solution, especially not from maintainers. Find the best possible solution yourself, or listen to the best advice from other community members.

Thanks for telling me this :) I'll keep in mind to look for duplicate issues before I reference then in my commits. And for the bad commit message, I was trying it on my fork and I didn't realize that I did not amend the commit while i created the PR. I'll remember it next time.
@sladyn98 IMHO Ignoring the warning didn't feel the best possible approach to the problem. I stand by my point that we should not ignore the errors only to make the build possible.
@frextrite  As discussed above, I first used a r" " to wrap all the invalid sequences in it. But then I faced two problems with the above solution

Sphinx documentation doesn't recognize r" ", and hence in the documentation, the sequences haven't been escaped rather they appeared as a string. eg:- (r"/*" appeared as r"/*", whereas it should detect the expression as only * after the netlify build of documentation) (I would be raising an issue there to inform about it soon)
Pycodestyle still emitted the warning of Invalid escape sequences

That's the reason why i did not use r to wrap the invalid sequences.
An alternative solution to the above problem was to use an extra backslash \ before the sequence. This solved the above two problems. Sphinx perfectly detected a \\* as * and Pycodestyle didn't complain too.
IMHO it is necessary to mention this somewhere in our documentation so that we don't encounter these errors in the future and cause build failures.

Yeah @Naveenaidu your right but  I suggested ignoring because you suggested that we would have to make changes in four files,else in my original comment on gitter I said that adding an extra '\' to avoid the escape sequences  error would be the best solution.Moreover @jayvdb mentioned in his orginal issue that sphinx would throw errors on r" "  wrapping ,my bad not to see that, anyways we would have to wait for the gometa linter issue to fixed for us to see the travis build and then proceed.Apart from that LGTM.
Please manually run the CI, especially the sphinx-build bits, as were mentioned in #2760

comments.bodyText:
What will eventually happen is interesting, and guides our CI structure a bit, but the purpose of CI is to break.
However, when fixing a breakage, the commit must only do the things absolutely necessary to fix the breakage.  Then the commit describes the fix, not the fix and some other nice stuff.  In the future, someone will be wanting to understand why you made the changes you made, and it will take much longer to understand if they can not see a green build containing only the minimal changes needed to unbreak it.

+from coalib.bearlib.abstractions.Linter import linter
+from dependency_management.requirements.GemRequirement import GemRequirement
+
+
+@linter(executable='slim-lint',
+        output_format='regex',
+        output_regex=r'(?P<origin>/[a-zA-Z].+):(?P<line>\d+)'
+                     r'\s\[(?P<severity>[a-zA-Z]+)\]\s(?P<message>.*)$')
+class SlimLintBear:
+    """
+    Linter for slim language.
+    More info: https://github.com/sds/slim-lint
+    """
+    LANGUAGES = {'Slim'}
+    REQUIREMENTS = {GemRequirement('slim_lint', '0.16.1')}
+    AUTHORS = {'The coala developers'}
+    AUTHORS_EMAILS = {'coala-devel@googlegroups.com'}

comments.bodyText: @soumya-ranjan7 @li-boxuan Review this please

@li-boxuan
I checked locally by adding JSONFormatBear on two sections and checked the appropriate message displayed when the json_sort value is either true or false.
Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this,
AssertionError: {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec04acf8>} != {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec05f9e8>}
This error is created by the check_results function inside LocalBearTestHelper.py .
It's comapring this whole string. But It should be comparing the Diff object's attribute values. This will always be false since the memory location will be always different.
In our codebase, the places where check_results is used was always used if the Diff object is None.
But here we are checking the message when the Diff is not None.
This type of test case is not tested previously. And check_results doesn't seem appropriate for this.
So what should I do in this case ?
Updated:
Approaches we can proceed with:
Creating a custom string reprsentation of diff object will resolve this.
Or defining a object.__eq__(self, other) function in coali.results.Diff would also work.

@naveentvelu check_results should work. Compare the strings from both of the Result objects yourself. (See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two). You  should be able to get your mistake, if not then post the entire pytest error on gitter.

@abhishalya
The check_results will not work because, we have a diff object which is not None. So when you compare two of them their ids get compared rather than their attributes.
If you see the above assertion error,
It is because of diffs(one of the attributes of 'result' class) which belongs to <class 'dict'>. This has a key-value pair filename : <class 'coalib.results.Diff.Diff'>.
In the current implementation of check_results, this key-value pair is directly being compared.This causes the assertion error.

See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two.

This is not needed here because there will always be mismatch in the id's of class objects even if they have the same attribute with same values.

@abhishalya @li-boxuan
Finally one of the approaches work, I added a def__repr__(self): function in Diff class. And It solved the above assertion error.
Should I create a issue along with PR for modifying the Diff class?
It's in coala/coala repo. https://github.com/coala/coala/blob/master/coalib/results/Diff.py

Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this ...

Post your code snippet, or just push with your unfinished code, so that people have a better understanding of your problem or find bugs with your code if there is any.

Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this ...

Post your code snippet, or just push with your unfinished code, so that people have a better understanding of your problem or find bugs with your code if there is an

I got it right now. The mistake was on my side. I passed the wrong expected diff value. Sorry @li-boxuan @abhishalya

Python34\lib\site-packages\coalib\testing\LocalBearTestHelper.py:228: in check_invalidity

comments.bodyText:
Appveyor build is failing due to failing tests/general/URLHeadBearTest.py::URLHeadBearTestPrerequisites::test_check_prerequisites
And in this commit, line 18 assertion was changed from True to checking for a failed head request to the check_connection_url. Was this intentional or this change was just made for the test to pass?
According to me, as of the time of the above mentioned commit, the head request to the old IP was already failing which resulted in the failure of the test and hence the assertion was modified so that it passes albeit it being wrong.

Adding to the previous comment, I backtracked to the point the original test case was replaced by a faulty one, I got the following results,
While sending a GET resuest using requests on some URL say,http://random.url, the requests module explicitly appends a trailing /(forward-slash) if it is missing from the url, hence the final URL that actually gets called becomes http://random.url/. Owing to this fact, in the custom_matcher defined in InvalidLinkBearTest.py at L42,request.url == URLHeadBear.check_connection_url would always return False since the value of original check_connection_url was defined to be http://216.58.218.174(Note: no forward-slash). Hence this condition would never be possible and the value of the status_code of the default connection url would always be None, though this behaviour was never intended.
When the original test case for this was written, it was asserting True on the returned value of the output of URLHeadBear.check_prerequisites(). It would always return the error string You are not connected to the internet., and when asserting this return, the test would pass, incorrectly.
To overcome this, the test was modified in this commit, to assert for the returned string instead of the asserting True. This too was incorrect, since in the custom matcher the check_connection_url URL was explicitly defined(atleast intended) to return a status code of 200OK, but this line was never hit as mentioned in the first paragraph.
Hence URLHeadBear.check_prerequisites() while testing would always return the error string You are not connected to the internet. and hence as mentioned in the above commit, instead of changing the mock properties to actually return 200OK if the head request was to check_connection_url URL, the actual test case was modified to check against the error string which was never intended.
In my defense, I was sleepy when I made the commit

features by changing restructuredtext-lint version from '1.0.0'

comments.bodyText:
Sorry if my review wasn't very clear. Take pyre_bad.py:2 for example.
    return 'string'
pyre says the error happens on line 2, column 4.
Now the problem comes:
What is column 4? Is the first column numbered 0 or 1?
Back to our example. It is clear that there are 4 spaces before return. Very likely, they consider the position of the first character of return, as the error position, i.e. the position of r. They call this position column 4. If that is the case, we can infer that they count column numbers from 0. However, coala counts from 1. column 4 needs to be converted into column 5 in coala.
But I am not sure. I don't know how they come up with column 4. Maybe they are referring to the last space before the word return, but chances are small. Maybe they have inconsistencies/bugs within their tool. You need to look up in their documentation (or even code), or ask them in their community.
It might not be an easy task, but such 'tiny' thing is important. coala needs to be accurate: sometimes upstream linters are not accurate, and we detect problems and help solve them.
Let me know if my words are not clear enough

Python 3.5.6 fail looks like it's because of an issue with pyre-check

issue.title: CPPCheckBear.py: Support language parameter
issue.body:
It adds the command line argument 'language' which can be
given whenever using the CPPCheckBear. It can hold two values
either C or C++.
Closes #2450

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use corobo mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
I have two different versions of cppcheck installed on two different machines. One of them has version 1.76.1 and other one has version 1.82 installed. However, when I used cppcheck on the newly added test file language_test.h which is a header file containing a bit of c++ specific code, on version 1.82, it did give an error like Code 'classFoo{' is invalid C code. Use --std or --language to configure the language. which means that version 1.82 considering .h files to be C specific. However, on cppcheck version 1.76.1 it doesn't give any error.
It seems that coala tests are using the previous version of cppcheck, and that's the reason the tests are failing.
What should be done here?

@gutsytechster , you need to build a test case which works with the version of cppclean that coala uses.
See the file bear-requirements.txt to see which version that is.

Isn't cppcheck and cppclean different?
And doesn't CPPCheckBear uses cppcheck?
Yes, my apology, I should have said cppcheck

@jayvdb can you review it?
I just need to know if I am taking the correct approach for using the Language class defined.

issue.title: mentors.html: Change mentor page year dynamically
issue.body:
Have the year on the GSoC mentor page change dynamically
based on the current month. If it's past September, the page
will show the next year, otherwise it will show the current year.
Closes #706

issue.title: _faq: Add details about cEPs to faq
issue.body:
This faq helps contributor in understanding about cEP and its
importance.
Closes #684

comments.bodyText: proposal proposed is a bit redundant, perhaps just proposed should convey the same meaning
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.

comments.bodyText: the contributor is intended to implement could be reworded to the contributor intends to implement
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.

comments.bodyText: not well-designed content could be changed to poorly designed content for clarity
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to not well-designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.

comments.bodyText: creating projects -> created projects and expanding on -> expanded on in order to preserve parallel structure from contributed to
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to not well-designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.
+
+Anyone planning to do GSoC with coala should be starting to write detailed project ideas in our [projects](https://github.com/coala/projects) repository. Experience tells us that the best GSoC students are the ones who heavily contributed to the project ideas website, creating projects from the issues, and expanding on existing ***.md*** files. And generally learning how to express complex technical ideas in the markup. If you can't explain your idea, and how you will achieve it, we probably don't want to mentor you doing that undefined project.

comments.bodyText: You can probably cut doing that undefined project from the end of that sentence, since it is already described earlier.
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,12 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP (coala Enhancement Proposal)** is proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor intends to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to poorly designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.
+
+Experience tells us that the best GSoC students are the ones who heavily contributed to the project ideas website, created projects from the issues, and expanded on existing ***.md*** files.
+
+So, if you are planning to do GSoC with coala you should be starting to write detailed project ideas in our [projects](https://github.com/coala/projects) repository. Also, you should learn how to express complex technical ideas in the markup because if you can't explain your idea, and how you will achieve it, we probably don't want to mentor you doing that undefined project.

issue.title: .travis.yml: Remove GitHub merge commit workaround
issue.body:
For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

CLAIMED or COMPLETED to those tasks which have max_instances=1
and an issues URL. Based upon these COMPLETED tasks, the instances
are being filtered out during cleansing.

issue.title: API limit exceed: Show modal
issue.body:
Shows the error in a user friendly way.
Fixes #127

comments.bodyText: debugging statements should not be in a PR.
please undo all of these whitespace changes.  They do not belong in your PR.  Create an issue if you want to enforce a new style on the code in the repository.
@jayvdb @blazeu which JavaScript style guide we use for this repository? Is it Airbnb? I would like to review this pull request.
We didn't specify or regulate a javascript style, but airbnb style seems to be the thing we were actually practicing.

@wisn Thank you for reviewing my Pull Request. I will change my code to follow the airbnb style guide.
This is the modal.

I'm having problem with the state to toggle the visibility of the modal. I am not able to update state within static defaultProps object. Please guide me on what changes I have to make here.
Consequently, the Ok button does not do anything.
PS: Please ignore the dark theme

I've made the requested changes - changed space indentation to 2 spaces and changed
const {identifier} to const { identifier }
@wisn Please review my PR
@123vivekr Does the modal works now? I don't know why the deploy preview always failed

@wisn I changed the props to functions and gave a show variable in the state. But the onResolve and onError functions are called (which in turn calls setState) multiple times and causes an infinite loop.
@wisn Please help figure out the cause of multiple calls to onError and onResolve.

issue.title: login-modal.jsx: Add regex for localhost IPs
issue.body:
Add regex /^127|^0/ to check for localhost
Closes #179

comments.bodyText: Looks fine, but not ideal. What if the website address starts from 127 or 0? e.g. 127.com, or even 127.0.0.1.com

Oh right!
How about this constraint starts with 127 or 0 and ends with a number [0-9]
hostname.match(/(^127|^0)?([0-9]$)/)
Or, I could split the hostname on . and check if the last index is a digit: hostname.split('.').pop().match(/[0-9]/)
Hmm, why not just check if hostname exactly matches 127.0.0.1 or 0.0.0.0?
I thought I'll handle cases of 127.x.x.x
@li-boxuan So should I just check for 127.0.0.1 and 0.0.0.0?
I think so, unless there is any other exception such that you have to use regex to match.
@bhawesh96 Are you still working on this?
No, I'm not. Please take it forward
@bhawesh96 this is your task.  Please finish it.

issue.title: Handle invalid tokens on login
issue.body:
When the token is invalid, sign-out the user and show login-modal again.
Fixes #72

comments.bodyText: Invalid user token -> GitHub token is invalid.
I'll change the message. Though I wasn't sure if the way I have handled this issue is a good user experience or not.
It works but is not ideal. Instead of an alert, I would be happier to see an error message displayed on the modal. Besides, the modal shouldn't be closed and then reopened.
@bhawesh96 , I have done a rebase using the bot; can you do a squash ?
On it.

I guess I messed up while squashing. I didn't really get what's happening here while rebasing and/or squashing :/
I just wanna keep this commit (cd1b558) in the PR
@li-boxuan I guess the PR is good to be reviewed now!

issue.title: Use dynamic date
issue.body:
Use 3 months earlier date dynamically rather than hardcoding
Closes #171

comments.bodyText:
could you re-arrange the logging so that earliestDate is always put into the log, i.e. add a log entry after this block of code -- before const ignoreAuthor...
Then there is always a record of what data set should be found in the deploy.
Here in this log entry, the output is quite strange.   For this deploy, which doesnt have EARLIEST_DATE or EARLIEST_DATE_PR set, it is:

To speed up netlify pr build, set earliest date threshold 2018-08-01T05:19:50+00:00

That log entry sounds like we should set the earliest date threshold to that date, yet .. that is the automatic date now, so it would be useless to set it at that date.
We would need to set it at a more recent date , if we wanted less data to be processed.
So the log message here needs rewriting now to complement the revised logic.
It is more useful to log the value of EARLIEST_DATE and EARLIEST_DATE_PR , and the final selected earliest date.  Then it is a fairly simple logical deduction that setting EARLIEST_DATE and EARLIEST_DATE_PR may be useful to override the automatically computed default.

I do not see the value in this restriction, especially not now with automatic sensible defaults earliest dates for PRs.
Due to your change, the only way this condition can be false is when an admin of the Netlify control panel sets EARLIEST_DATE_PR to be earlier than EARLIEST_DATE , which is silly.  But if they really want to do that, we should respect that ... maybe they are doing stress testing or something like that.
I'm sorry I didn't really get what's to be done here. Can you please brief me a little more?

I understand that the if condition is always going to be false unless an admin of the Netlify control panel sets EARLIEST_DATE_PR to be earlier than EARLIEST_DATE.
But, what am I supposed to do about it in the code?
@bhawesh96 Remove this condition; the restriction is not valuable now, especially after your change
You shouldn't remove this line.
Obviously, this will cause a syntax error. Please run it locally first, at least you should make sure it does not cause any linting error/compilation error before you push.
Really sorry about it. I missed the linting. Wouldn't hurry to push now-onward.

issue.title: Remove unnecessary parameter
issue.body: fixes #137

comments.bodyText: Could you please explain why have you removed state?

In this route, if the user hit the /dashboard path in URL then he will be directed to /.  so in this function, we are not changing any state of the component. so it was used but its value is not used.
The work of redirecting is done by history.push() function.
@shikharvaish28  please review the pull request.

This is fine. However, the commit itself 3233746 has a problem. We should not use browserHistory here, but history 
  
    
      gh-board/src/router.jsx
    
    
         Line 5
      in
      f08f19b
    
    
    
    

        
          
           import history from './history'; 
        
    
  

 instead.
It's okay if you leave your change as it is, since it is a newcomer issue. After this gets merged we create a new issue to replace browserHistory with history.
Created an issue #163

@aditya81070 You need to follow the commit guidelines http://api.coala.io/en/latest/Developers/Writing_Good_Commits.html
Also your pull request does not indicate the issue you are solving.
@PrajwalM2212  I will improve this in the future. Should I also change commit message for this time?
@PrajwalM2212  I have changed the commit message.
@srivama @rishabhgarg25699 @PrajwalM2212 I have squashed three commits to one and also changed commit messages according to the Coala guidelines.
@li-boxuan  I did the commit message according to the guide.
@li-boxuan What should I do now?
@li-boxuan I have changed the commit message
This is not a bug so you should use Closes instead of Fixes.
@aditya81070 Are you still doing this?

@aditya81070 , needs a manual rebase to resolve conflicts
See https://coala.io/git
@jayvdb Okay I am doing this.
Abandoned.

issue.title: README.rst: Add Build and Development instructions
issue.body:
The commit adds instructions for running coala-html on a local system.
Closes #135

comments.bodyText:
This command is Ubuntu specific. Either

Provide install commands for other major distros(Fedora, Arch, OpenSuse etc) or
Provide a link to Official Installation Documentation of NodeJS, so that users not on Ubuntu can seamlessly install NodeJS
comments.diffHunk:
@@ -70,9 +70,74 @@ We appreciate any help!
 BUILD & DEVELOPMENT
 -------------------
 
-Run ``python3 setup.py install``
+1. Clone the *coala-html* repository
 
-Note: You need to have bower installed before you may install the python packages.
+::
+
+  $ git clone https://github.com/coala/coala-html.git
+
+2. Install latest version of **Node.js**
+
+- *Configure Node.js PPA*
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo apt-get install curl python-software-properties
+    $ curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_11.x | sudo bash -
+
+- *Install Node.js and npm*
+
+::
+
+  $ sudo apt-get install nodejs

+
+::
+
+    $ sudo npm install -g bower
+
+4. Change the directory to *coala-html* and run following command to install dependencies
+
+::
+
+    $ python setup.py install
+
+5. Install **coala-bears**
+
+::
+
+    $ pip install coala-bears
+
+6. Allow permissions to **root user** to install node packages
+
+::
+
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.npm
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.config
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.cache/bower/registry/registry.bower.io/lookup/
+    $ sudo chown -R $USER:$GROUP ~/.cache/bower/packages
+
+7. Run **coala-html** to display results from *coala-json*

issue.title: .coafile: Update .coafile to new format
issue.body:
Closes #148

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
Please consider helping us by reviewing other peoples pull requests as well:

pick up any PR at https://coala.io/review
review it (check https://coala.io/reviewing for more info)
if you are sure that it needs work, use cobot mark wip <URL> to get it out
of the review queue.

The more you review, the more your score will grow at coala.io and we will
review your PRs faster!

comments.bodyText:
Hi, please amend your commit message from .coafile: Update .coafile to newer format  to .coafile: Update .coafile to new format  
Use the command git commit --amend and make the changes suggested above

comments.bodyText:
Line contains following spacing inconsistencies:

No newline at EOF.

Origin: SpaceConsistencyBear, Section: spacing.

individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will

pass on every single commit!

of the review queue.

review your PRs faster!
